docs.lead_paragraph: UnitedHealth says it will continue offering some of the popular consumer protections required by the federal health care law, even if the Supreme Court strikes down the entire law later this month.

docs.lead_paragraph: Even if the health care law is overturned, or repealed after the next election, the economic pressure to care differently for more people at lower cost is irreversible.

headline.seo: Maimonides Medical Center Grapples With Health Care Uncertainty
headline.main: Hospitals Aren’t Waiting for Verdict on Health Care Law
headline.print_headline: Health Care Law’s Fate Aside, Hospitals Evolve

docs.abstract: Hospitals across the country, like Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn, are already implementing the policies driving the federal health care law despite the uncertainty of its future; the Supreme Court is to decide whether the law will stand, but even if the health care law is overturned, or repealed after the next election, the economic pressure to care differently for more people at lower cost is irreversible.
docs.snippet: Even if the health care law is overturned, or repealed after the next election, the economic pressure to care differently for more people at lower cost is irreversible.

docs.lead_paragraph: Giant aquariums now soothe pediatric patients at Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn. It has added welcome signs in 10 languages, a state-of-the-art cardiac operating room and programs to keep chronically ill adults safely at home. But as Pamela S. Brier, the chief executive, was walking to the main entrance last week, she spotted a rain-soaked plastic bag on the front steps. Millions of dollars in revenue now depend on improving patients' perceptions of the hospital. ''I can't stand it,'' Ms. Brier muttered, and she darted over, her cream chiffon dress fluttering, to scoop up the litter herself.

headline.main: Health Care Law's Fate Aside, Hospitals Evolve

docs.abstract: Editorial criticizes House Republicans for proposing to gut the federal agencies designed to prevent economic meltdowns like the Great Recession of 2007; observes that the proposed cuts are the latest in a long series of efforts by Republicans to keep the government from tempering even the most economically dangerous desires of business.

docs.abstract: News analysis; the political ramifications of the Supreme Court's ruling on the Affordable Care Act will be big, regardless of whether the justices uphold the law or not, but experts say the practical effects will probably be less earth-shattering than people assume.

docs.lead_paragraph: The current election is producing very few goose bumps, except perhaps among those who get all tingly when they view billionaire-financed attack ads. The incumbent, who drew adoring throngs last time, cannot always fill a room this time. The challenger's risk-averse, carefully plotted strategy is a business plan worthy of a Harvard M.B.A. - and consciously the antithesis of the improvisational, let's-take-a-shot style of the war hero Republican nominee of four years ago.

headline.main: Political Memo: Not the '08 Campaign, but More May Be at Stake

docs.abstract: Political memo; the 2012 presidential race between Pres Obama and presumptive Republican nominee Mitt Romney is shaping up in many ways to be more important for the debate on the role of government and the direction of the country than 2008 was; unlike the last race, when both candidates competed for the center and the differences between the parties often seemed bridgeable, the 2012 campaign is asking voters to choose between starkly different paths. Photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Delegates of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, the largest component of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., will vote on June 21 for a new president.

headline.seo: Fight Heats Up to Lead One of Nation’s Largest Unions
headline.main: For Labor, a Fight to Lead Heats Up
headline.print_headline: For Labor, a Fight to Lead Heats Up

docs.abstract: American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees will hold elections to replace its longtime president Gerald W McEntee; candidates Lee Saunders and Danny Donohue are competing to helm an massive organization that faces falling membership and has been humbled by its failure to oust Wisconsin's anti-union governor, Scott Walker.
